revision.text:
[[Image:Rd to SS.jpg|thumb|300px|The road to San Salvador, leaving from Apopa. Vertical road leads to [[Quezaltepeque, La Libertad|Quezaltepeque]]. The volcano of [[San Salvador]] is seen in the distance.]] [[El Salvador]] has [[transport]] links by [[Road transport|road]], [[Rail transport|rail]], [[Sea transport|sea]] and [[Air transport|air]].
El Salvador has over 10,000 km of roads, and one passenger rail service. There are several [[seaports]] on the [[Pacific Ocean]], and two international [[airports]].
==Railways== {{main|Rail transport in El Salvador}} A weekday passenger service links [[San Salvador]] and [[Apopa]], a journey of 40 minutes.<ref>[http://www.fenadesal.gob.sv/tren_pasajeros.php Servicio de Tren de Pasajeros], FENADESAL, 2009</ref> Of a total of 602 km [[Narrow gauge railway|narrow gauge]] ({{RailGauge|3ft}}) rail, much is abandoned. In November 2013 the government rail agency FENADESAL announced plans for development of four electrified railways serving San Salvador, Sitio del Niño ([[La Libertad Department, El Salvador|La Libertad]]), [[El Salvador International Airport]], [[La Unión, El Salvador|La Unión]], and the Honduran frontier.<ref>Jaime García, [http://www.elsalvador.com/mwedh/nota/nota_completa.asp?idCat=47673&idArt=8353978 ''La CEPA construirá nuevo sistema de ferrocarril en el país'' (CEPA will build a new rail system in the country")], elsalvador.com, 25 November 2013</ref>
===Railway links with adjacent countries=== * {{flagicon|Guatemala}} [[Transport in Guatemala|Guatemala]] - {{RailGauge|3ft}} gauge both countries, currently closed.<ref>[http://www.iexplore.com/dmap/El+Salvador/Do's+and+Don'ts El Salvador Travel Tips | iExplore<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * {{flagicon|Honduras}} [[Transport in Honduras|Honduras]] - none * A new railway to be known as [[FERISTSA]] was proposed in 2005 to connect Mexico with Panama, passing through El Salvador.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnamericas.com/news/infrastructure/Shaw_Group_in_talks_with_US_railroad_cos_for_Feristsa_project |accessdate=2010-10-16 |title=Shaw Group in talks with US railroad cos for Feristsa project, Central America, Infrastructure, news }}</ref>
==Highways== [[Image:El-Salvador-Bus.jpg|thumb|300px|The bus running between Santa Ana and San Salvador.]] *''total:'' 10,029 km *''paved:'' 1,986 km (including 327 km of [[Highway]]s) *''unpaved:'' 8,043 km (1999 est.)
The [[RN-21 (Boulevard Diego Holguin)|RN-21 (Bulevar Monseñor Romero)]] (East–West) is the very first freeway to be built in [[El Salvador]] and in [[Central America]]. The freeway passes the northern area of the city of [[Santa Tecla, El Salvador|Santa Tecla]], [[La Libertad Department (El Salvador)|La Libertad]]. It has a small portion serving [[Antiguo Cuscatlan]], La Libertad, and merges with the [[RN-5 (Autopista Comalapa)]] (East–West, Boulevard de Los Proceres/Autopista del Aeropuerto) in [[San Salvador]].
The total length of the RN-21 is {{convert|9.95|km|mi}} and is currently working as a traffic reliever in the metropolitan area. The RN-21 was named in honor of Monseñor Romero. The first phase of the highway was completed in 2009, and the second phase in November 2012.
==Ports and harbors==
=== Pacific Ocean === * [[Acajutla]] * Puerto Cutuco * [[La Libertad, El Salvador|La Libertad]] * [[La Unión, El Salvador|La Unión]] * [[Puerto El Triunfo]]
==Merchant marine== none (1999 est.)
==Airports== [[Image:comalapa airport.jpg|thumb|300px|[[El Salvador International Airport]].]] 75 (2006 est.)
===Airports - with paved runways=== *''total:'' 4 *''over 3,047 m:'' 1 *''1,524 to 2,437 m:'' 1 *''914 to 1,523 m:'' 2 (2006 est.)
===Airports - with unpaved runways=== *''total:'' 71 *''1,524 to 2,437 m:'' 1 *''914 to 1,523 m:'' 14 *''under 914 m:'' 56 (2006 est.)
===Heliports=== 1 (2006 est.)
===Airports by name===
* [[El Salvador International Airport]] * [[Ilopango International Airport]] * [[El Tamarindo]]
